pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found the light bulb demonstrations engaging and helpful in understanding abstract concepts. The live experiment with the plastic sheet and lightbulb sparked interest, while the separation of charges demonstration was particularly intriguing. Visual representations, like the lightbulb lighting, aided comprehension. Some students, however, struggled to keep up with the pace of demonstrations and associated explanations.
input:
The conservation of energy question was very tricky. I was indecisive between the correct answer and the “difference in charge” answer, so I felt that I learned the most from this question.
The explanation of your plastic sheet and lightbulb experiment was really neat and caught my interests. 
I thought having the visual examples was interesting because it makes topics easier to understand.
I found it interesting how similar electric force is to gravitational force. 
I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
The group work in solving the distribution of charge
What I found most interesting today was that there can be two components of an electrostatic force. I found this interesting because  I'm working with forces that are invisible. 
Energy conservation in particle physics with a gamma ray photon being split into an electron and positron was very intriguing since I've never learned much about gamma rays in the past.
The amount of interaction we were able to have with you as an instructor and in breakout rooms was interesting.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
 I found interesting how similar the forces caused by charges and gravity are. 
 I like that the math is pretty consistent and the laws and theorems are pretty easily definable I just get messed up when you're doing demonstrations that move really quickly and the words go over my head.
 I found the clicker question about F and F' very interesting.
 The shell theory was a very interesting concept and easy to understand because it is so similar to how you treat round objects in translational motion which helped me understand it better
 i really like learning about the electric charges and i like learning about electrons after taking so many chemistry classes 
 The final question about charges on the corners of a square. 
 The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.
 I found that the different ways charges spread out was interesting and I understood the differences between all of the examples of them
 I enjoyed doing the practice problems because I believe that is the best way to learn. 
 Electric charge properties 
 I found the Part 5: Charges Spread Out video the most interesting! The first one of 50:50 seemed to be expected but I found the grounded conductor and induced charge to be interesting

I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.
suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases:** Instead of repeatedly mentioning "interesting," "found interesting," or "was interesting," use more varied adjectives or phrases to convey student engagement, such as "captivating," "intriguing," or "held their attention."

2. **Consolidate similar points:** Combine the feedback about the light bulb demonstrations and other visual examples into a single point to make the summary more concise. For instance, "Students appreciated the visual demonstrations, with the light bulb experiment and separation of charges being particularly engaging and helpful in understanding abstract concepts."

3. **Clarify the challenge:** Instead of saying "struggled to keep up," consider rephrasing it to "found the pace of some demonstrations and explanations challenging to follow," to better convey the students' experience without using negative language.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the visual demonstrations, particularly the light bulb experiment and separation of charges, captivating and instrumental in grasping abstract concepts. The live experiment with the plastic sheet and lightbulb sparked curiosity, while the separation of charges demonstration held their attention. Some students, however, found the pace of certain demonstrations and explanations challenging to follow.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Gaussian surface concept challenging, with common queries including the choice of Gaussian surface shapes (any shape possible? Multiple shapes for the same answer?), understanding the electric field inside vs. outside a solid, uniform, insulating sphere, and applying Gauss' law to conductors and insulators. Some students struggled with calculating areas of Gaussian surfaces and understanding the impact of charge distribution on flux.
input:
i think the last practice problem we did in class could've been done slower to make it easier to comprehend. i had to think it over for a few minutes after class ended for it to come to me
I did not understand why the electric field inside of a solid, uniform, insulating sphere (r<R) is greater than the field outside of it (r>R).
I think the angle at which flux flows from an object is a bit confusing. The first problem on the concept quiz deals with this. 
I think the idea and concepts make sense, but I am confused about what shapes to choose as the Gaussian surface. Can you choose any shape? Are there multiple shapes that will still give the same answer as the cylinder? Also, the conductor vs insulator in reference to Gauss' law is confusing to me
The orientation of planar electric fields and cylindrical Gaussian surface
More examples would be helpful for further understanding. 
Figuring out what Gaussian surface to draw in problems 
I was not too confused but the field lines of the right angle planes question for the quiz was confusing. 
Nothing was too confusing. The only part I found a little difficult was the different gauss fields around the uniformly charged inner sphere. Just transitioning from one layer to the next for me slightly confused in your last example problem video.
I was confused about why we find the areas of the three different parts of the cylinder, and how we do this.
 The second question on the concept quiz confused me, I wasn't sure how positive and negative charges being outside or inside affect flux.
 Are these the only three symmetries we will work with?

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on resistors/resistance engaging, with many appreciating the real-world connections. They understood the ease of calculating resistance in series and the concept of batteries' internal resistance. The application of Ohm's Law and circuit analysis was well-received, with practice problems being particularly helpful for exam preparation. The relationship between power, resistors, and electromotive force was also found interesting, with students enjoying the practical application of physics concepts.
input:
I found the copper wire example interesting because it was related to real world incidences of touching wires and how dangerous it can be. 
All of the different ways to use Ohm's Law by rearranging the equation
I found circuits interesting because I am able to see how it is used in real life very often. 
I thought it was nice at how easy calculating resistance was after proving with algebra that the resistors in series can just be additively calculated 
Ohms law 
The fact that batteries actually have more volts than displayed as it loses it over time is interesting. 
Circuit analysis

I found the practice problems most interesting because we went in depth with problem solving and I feel like it well help me prepare for the exam 
I liked learning about power and barrieres, an object we use everyday, and how it works.
 Power and how it relates to resistors 
 electromotive force was really interesting 
 The circuits in general are interesting.

 Applying physics concepts to real life applications

 the relation to energy and the combination of many past concepts

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Current/Resistance engaging, with key takeaways including the comparison of current flow in saltwater versus freshwater, and the application of Ohm's law to real-world scenarios like a car starting. They also appreciated the hands-on aspect of creating series and parallel circuit scenarios, and the mathematical aspect of calculating equivalent capacitance and current flow through conductors.
input:
I thought the fact that saltwater has less resistivity than freshwater was the most interesting!
I thought the example about the lightning bolt hitting the water was really cool. I also thought that the difference the current flows through saltwater and freshwater was interesting, even though it wasn't supposed to be part of our lesson.
The circuit problems were enlightening.
Solving for the time it takes for electrons to move from a car battery to the starter motor and understanding that the result does not need to be a small number in order for the car to start, since there is still a lot of current flowing to the the motor.
I found the parallel capacitors interesting because you are able to combine capacitors together when they are parallel to each other 
Examining electricity in motion is reaply interesting after looking at it static for so long

Resistivity of uniform wire 
Drift velocity and current resistance 
I thought it was interesting creating the series scenarios. It's sort of engaging cresting your own picture of a circuit. 
I found it interesting that capacitances can be added to get Ceq.
 Calculating capacitance in circuits
 How the current "flows"through a conductor
 We can calculate the numeric value of complicated electrical concepts in physics.  
 I found it interesting how we are now drawing our circuits in series and parallel. Itvs interesting to see how electricity works in the real world.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of integrals, particularly in calculating potential energy and electric fields, challenging. Many struggled with selecting appropriate bounds for integrals, with one student incorrectly solving a problem due to improper bounds. Some found the transition from electric field to potential energy confusing, and several sought more detailed explanations and examples for integral setups, especially for problems involving zero bounds or dipoles. A few students also expressed confusion about the difference between voltage potential energy, potential energy, and regular voltage. To improve understanding, students suggested providing more examples and explanations, especially for complex concepts like partial derivatives and the behavior of conductors in electric fields.
input:
The integral part and the last problem that we did. I am always confused about how to set up the problem.
I was mostly confused about how to pick bounds for the integral in solving for potential energy. Ultimately, my answer for a question was wrong Bc I chose wrongly.
Today's class was really great! For once I felt like I was following along with everything, and understanding the material. The explanation from finding electric potential from electric field could have been explained a little more, I feel.
The practice problem with the integral needed more details in today's class. I needed more clarification in a group of the whole class rather than my breakout room. 
the last top hat question could've had more explanation. i was confused on how to set it up
I was confused how to find work using an integral when one of the bounds was zero. 
Trying to figure out what dq should equal while integrating 
Getting electric fields from electric potentials? 
The concept addressed in the second concept question, regarding how fields are affected by other fields, was confusing. 
I was confused about how to take partial derivatives, and when it makes sense to do so.
 The difference between the voltage potential energy, the potential energy and then regular volatage. I just kept getting lost with the symbols and meanings
 Overall more examples, not necessarily solving but the setup, would be helpful as well as more explanation of dipoles and their potential energy 
 The potential energy of the field was confusing. 
 The second question on the second concept quiz was about conductors. If you could explain the answer in class that would be great. I cannot seem to wrap my head around it. 
 I didn't find anything really confusing, but I think it would be helpful to look at calculating potential from an electric field again 
 I found it confusing when to set the initial potential to zero.

input:
I found it interesting using the loop rule to solve the last problem because it made the problem more simple than I initially thought. 
i liked that no matter which path you took to find current in a circuit, you'll get the same value. 
The computer circuit was the most interesting part of class today because I would never be able to understand that in my life. 
Grounding and how it changes the calculation for current
I found the part where the professor left the class as funny. It really gave us all a break in the middle
Current here split up when you add grounded points to a circuit 
Batteries and circuits are intriguing. I like to learn about currents and how energy within batteries work
The circuit analysis about the voltage in loops summing to 0. 
I found the ammeters and voltmeters interesting because they can both be used in the same circuit but for different reasons. 
I thought your explanation of ammeters and voltmeters was very well done. This topic that was previously confusing to me in high school is now much clearer. I thought it was interesting thinking about how current runs through a wire and why each of these have to have very different resistances.
 I've used multimeters before. But never considered that just measuring would impact the circuit itself so your reading will never be 100% true. Was just a little interesting and never thought about it before. since the meter will just extend the circuit and draw some energy.  neat. 
 Internal resistance 
 I found the videos explaining the concepts most interesting.
 The grounding was very interesting. 
 How ammeters and voltmeters play a role in circuits 
 Learning how voltmeters are able to get accurate voltage readings without leaking much current out of the circuit by being connected in parallel with resistors/capacitors.
 I thought grounding was interesting. I never understood what grounding meant before. 
 Voltmeters and ammeters are really interesting in that I think it's cool that we can actually measure these concepts (voltage and current) pretty easily
 Learning the paths circuits take and what way the current flows I found to be very interesting. It's cool to see how current flows in real wires and in real life. 
 i thought that the applications of grounding and how that could simplify complicated circuits was interesting 
 I thought the ammeter and voltmeter were the most interesting part, especially after the concept quiz and seeing how the voltmeter was the emf
 I thought it was interesting that all grounded points are connected to each other.
 The amount of info we can determine from a simple circuit with proper analysis is very cool.

one thing that was confusing for me was the actual calculations regarding the topic. I was a bit confused on that part of the concept quiz. 
Calculating cylindrical capacitors
The difference between the two variables that use U was very confusing. How energy relates to capacitance just wasn't clear to me.

I'm a bit confused by how the equations relate together so more explanation and examples would be great. 
The concept of dielectrics weakening the electric field inside of a capacitor.  In today's class I found it confusing how the units work between charge and capacitance and electric potential. I found it confusing what a farad is.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Specific Formula Confusion**: Instead of mentioning the general confusion about applying capacitance formulas, specify that students were unsure about the universal use of the equation (0.5cv²) for any shape, despite knowing that shape affects capacitance.

   *Revised*: Students were puzzled by the universal application of the formula (0.5cv²) for any shape, questioning why it works when capacitance is shape-dependent.

2. **Distinguish U and V**: Rather than grouping U and V together as a confusing pair, highlight that students struggled to understand the difference between these two variables and their relation to energy and capacitance.

   *Revised*: Students found it challenging to distinguish between U (energy density) and V (voltage), and how they relate to capacitance and energy.

3. **Simplify Dielectric Confusion**: Instead of mentioning conflicting diagrams, focus on the core misunderstanding about how dielectrics weaken the electric field inside a capacitor.

   *Revised*: Students were unclear about how dielectrics decrease the electric field within a capacitor, questioning how the electric field is weakened without being shown to flow through the material.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY**: Students struggled with the application of capacitance formulas, specifically questioning the universal use of the equation (0.5cv²) across different shapes, despite knowing shape's role in capacitance. The concepts of partial integrals and multiple charges in calculations also caused confusion. Students found it challenging to distinguish between U (energy density) and V (voltage), and how they relate to capacitance and energy. Additionally, students were unclear about how dielectrics decrease the electric field within a capacitor, questioning the mechanism behind this weakening effect. Lastly, students were curious about the practical applications of capacitors and the units involved, particularly the farad.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on flux engaging and informative. They appreciated the practical applications, such as understanding Faraday cages and using Gauss's Law to simplify complex problems. Visual aids, like diagrams and field lines, were particularly helpful in grasping the concept. The integration of electric flux with dot products and the use of Gaussian surfaces for problem-solving were also highlighted as interesting aspects. However, some students still seek further clarification and practice to solidify their understanding of the topic.
input:
I really like the flux topic. The concept questions about these were something that I found relatively easy to answer after watching the lecture videos in advance. 
The faraday cage video was really interesting.
It was interesting to see the way that insulators and conductors reacted to electric fields and how that affected the flux
I found Faraday cages cancelling out external electric fields very interesting. It was also neat how the internal cap of a cylinder imbedded in a conductor has no flux, but the external end does.
I liked the electric flux portion of the lecture this week. I liked reading the diagrams and solving for the charge in the example with the box. 
Flux and field lines with Gaussian 
I found Gauss's Law interesting based on the fact that it can simplify a very difficult problem
I find it interesting that such a complex value like flux can be measured by a dot product and not a more complicated calculus method. 
The diagrams helped me picture how flux works
I found GaussIan surfaces pretty interesting since you can draw a shape and then make solving Gauss' law easier to solve.
 conductors 
 How we can use field lines to determine the charge of a surface
 I found it most interesting that when E is a constant, it can be pulled out of the integration and all that's left is area.
 Akdjalkjds alj Sloan sdlkaj sdlkja lady a
 I found it interesting that an electric field can flow through a surface. I also found it interesting that you can calculate the charge enclosed in an area
 I thought it was interesting how we can prove the equation for E is correct by doing some math.
 I found out that Gauss's law is just flux over an imaginary shape, like a potato. I think this helped clear up much of my confusion.
 I had heard of Faraday Cages but I didn't really know what they were or how they worked so that was interesting
 The water example gave me an idea of the concept, but I still don't feel strong about the subject.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on integrals engaging, appreciating how they bridge calculus and physics. They enjoyed seeing integrals simplify with constant pulling and substitution, and found applications like calculating electric fields from charge distributions particularly interesting. Group work in breakout rooms and real-world problem-solving examples were well-received. Some students noted the connection to their current math classes, while others found the visual representations, such as electric field diagrams, helpful. Overall, students expressed enthusiasm for the practical application of calculus in physics.
input:
i thought it was really cool to see the integrations and see how one subject goes to the other
How the integrals simplify as you pull out constants and make substitutions. 
How the Calculus concepts were applied to extended charges (integrals, u-substitution)
I found it interesting that a single sliver of a rod or ring with uniform charge can be used to calculate the entire electric field produced by the object
I found that integration is very useful to solve problems in physics. It helped me translate skills from calculus to solve problems in physics.
Example problems
I enjoyed the fact that we kept going into breakout rooms in small intervals. It helped us bounce ideas off each other.
I found the integrals interesting because it matches up with what I am doing in math class right now. 
The checking as a point charge and line charge
i found that the different charge densities were  interesting

 I found it interesting how calculus integrates into physics. It was cool to see how the integral can be used to calculate an electric field. 
 I found most interesting how we can use integration to determine the electric field
 Compared to the ring of charge, the line of charge is pretty simple and easy to understand
 The mathematical formulas that define abstract electrical concepts are really interesting.
 I found it interesting how an integral can be used to calculate any shape of forces. 
 I love math especially calculus so to see any type is always refreshing. I always enjoy seeing when both are involved in each other (I'm learning some physics in calc 3 right now too)

 The electric field diagrams were easy to learn and interesting.

 Definitely the electric field demonstrations we watched on youtube. It was really cool to see actual electric fields

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on RC Circuits engaging, with the balloon analogy and real-world tie-ins being particularly memorable. The concept of current decaying exponentially with time constant RC resonated with them, as did the mathematical approach of writing circuit equations and forming differential equations. They also appreciated the similarities between magnetic and electric fields, and the practical application of calculating voltage and charges in real-life circuits.
input:
The lost interesting thing is the video demonstrations
I found the balloon tophat question most interesting about today's class because I thought too hard about it at first and once it was explained it was an “ah” moment
I found the balloon example interesting because it tied what we were learning to a more real world experience/possibility 
The rc circuit stuff
The equation for magnetic fields on point chargesThe equation for magnetic fields on point charges
It's interesting how the current of an RC circuit is essentially a fraction of the original current dependant on the time constant. 
I enjoy learning about magnets, their properties and their fields
I found the magnetic field lines interesting because no matter how small they get they will always have a north and a south end. 
I thought it was really interesting that capacitors ALL charge at the same “rate” which is RC seconds. Also found it interesting that capacitors are never fully charged. the graph was a good representation of this since I feel most of us are very familiar what an asymptote is and what it represents as a graphical function 
Magnetic field lines and  multiloop circuits 
 The rc time unit was interesting. 
 I really like that magnetic field lines follow the same rules as electric field lines. I also like that magnetic monopoles haven't been discovered! 
 How you can split up multi loop circuits into separate branches 
 I really enjoyed writing the circuit equations in terms of one another and then forming differential equations. On top of already enjoying this unit, I really like this kind of math as well
 It was neat how we used the very basic loop rule to build up to a separable differential equation that solves q(t).
 I thought it was interesting how we have never been able to create a magnet with the same poles. Especially since it has the possibility to be useful for technology. 
 It's interesting how electrons move in circular motion around a magnetic field. Also it is interesting how many times we use the cross product. 
 I found it interesting that magnetic fields are so similar to electric fields.
 I think it is interesting how the graphs of charging and discharging a capacitor are able to tell us a lot
 Direction of vectors 
 How the magnetic field acts 
 Magnetism's ability to affect a charge. 
 I found it interesting how we are calculating the voltage and charges for real life circuits.

I thought it was really interesting that capacitors ALL charge at the same “rate” which is RC seconds. Also found it interesting that capacitors are never fully charged. the graph was a good representation of this since I feel most of us are very familiar what an asymptote is and what it represents as a graphical function

The rc time unit was interesting.
How you can split up multi loop circuits into separate branches
I really enjoyed writing the circuit equations in terms of one another and then forming differential equations. On top of already enjoying this unit, I really like this kind of math as well
I found it interesting how we are calculating the voltage and charges for real life circuits.

input:
n/a
Much was very thorough and clear. I had some issues understanding the diagrams at first, not sure why. Seems a few others were confused with how to interpret the diagram as well. Nevertheless, it was a good self problem solving period. and when the prof explained, it was clear and well executed. I understood more being confused and then being enlightened and shown how the diagram was supposed to represent the particles and their charges. furthermore, after the first diagram it seemed like I felt I was absorbing s a lotmore from the concepts you were trying to get through to us.
I think the example pertaining to the charges arranged in a square was a little confusing. Particularly deriving the r value.
I thought that everything was very clear, however I felt that some of the time given for the TopHat questions was insufficient. There were multiple times where I scrambled to put in an answer that ended up being wrong because I was one or two steps away from the right answer but didn't have time to finish the problem. 
What I found unclear was the lightbulb lighting up due to the work done by the professor. It was stated that the work done caused the lightbulb to light up and the electrons moving into the lightbulb.
The uses for coulombs law in specific 
In today's class the Shell theorem was very confusing to me. I did not understand how it works. 
The idea of grounding was unclear to me. I did not understand how charge can be left over in a particle after it has been grounded.
Overall, today's class was really good! I thought that each tophat question was well explained. I was a little confused with some of the math steps you took in simplifying, because you never showed any conversions, but the whole concept was clear.
I thought some of the problems we did in class were confusing. I did end up finding the right answers but I think the explanation in class could've been more in-depth.
 I was a bit confused with the concept question on tophat about the ratio of charges, but after explaining, it made more sense. 
 I really didn't understand the second top hat question with the two particles that were repelling eachother and then a third particle touches both of them respectively. I know how the first particle touches the third particle so it's q value and the first particles q value are halved. I also know how the second particle touches the third particle and doing (1/2+1)/2 is 3/4 for both particles. I just didn't know where to go from there to solve for F' or F because I didn't know what it defined as F' and F. You probably mentioned it though and it just went too quickly for me.

 The beginning of the lecture about charges was a bit rushed and I think it would be a valuable thing to go over since it is the building blocks of electric forces
 i enjoyed today's class. i struggled when all the forces were being applied onto the one force. i didn't understand this because i couldn't seem to figure out why that one force just became 0. 
 I think today's class was good. The breakout rooms did help me meet some new students. I was also able to understand the content well, as I solved the questions on my own before the professor. It would be great if we could have Q n A sometime during lecture. 
 I was confused about the way to break up the components in the last problem. I forgot about vector math from physics 1. The breakout room for one of the problems was not helpful, my group did not participate.
 I was a little bit confused on Shell Theorems in today's class because the two Theorems seem to be very similar and I'm having trouble understanding the difference between the two. 
 I felt that the lecture was well explained. I believe that one would only find it confusing if they didn't watch the prerecorded lectures before hand. 
 Coulomb's law Shell Theorems
 I found the second shell theorem to be confusing. Is there no electric force on the particle because the shell it is in is charged?

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Dipole Behavior in Uniform Fields**: Since multiple students found dipoles in uniform fields confusing, consider dedicating more time to explain and provide additional examples on this topic. Specifically, address the behavior of dipoles when the field is perpendicular or parallel to the dipole moment.

2. **Explain Electric Field, Force, and Potential Energy Relationships**: To help students understand these interrelated concepts better, provide a clear, step-by-step explanation of how they are connected. Offer worked examples to illustrate these relationships, focusing on when the potential energy of a dipole is maximum.

3. **Slow Down Pace for Practice Problems**: As mentioned by several students, slowing down the pace during practice problems would allow them to better follow along, take notes, and absorb the information. Consider pausing after each step of a problem to allow students to catch up and ask questions.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with understanding dipole behavior in uniform electric fields, particularly when the field is perpendicular or parallel to the dipole moment. Clarifying the relationship between electric fields, forces, and potential energy, with a focus on when dipole potential energy is maximum, would greatly benefit students. To enhance learning, slowing the pace during practice problems and allowing time for note-taking and questions is crucial. Additionally, providing clear explanations and worked examples for the application of the binomial theorem and simple charge distributions would help students better grasp these concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the "Monkey Problem" engaging and intriguing, with many citing it as the most interesting part of the lecture. The problem, involving a monkey falling from a tree while a hunter aims to shoot it, helped illustrate the independence of horizontal and vertical motions in projectile motion. Students appreciated the real-world application and the counterintuitive result that aiming at the monkey's current position will always hit it, regardless of when the monkey drops. Visual aids, such as videos and breakout room discussions, were particularly helpful in understanding and visualizing the problem.

2. **Clarify the Counterintuitive Result**: To make the summary more concise and focused, consider rephrasing the counterintuitive result. Instead of "aiming at the monkey's current position will always hit it," you could say "students were fascinated by the paradoxical outcome that aiming at the monkey's current position ensures a hit, regardless of when the monkey drops."

3. **Highlight the Key Concept**: To emphasize the focus on the Monkey Problem, start the summary with the key concept illustrated by the problem. For example, "Students found the 'Monkey Problem' particularly engaging as it effectively demonstrated the independence of horizontal and vertical motions in projectile motion." This suggestion helps to immediately focus the summary on the Monkey Problem and its educational value.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on vector addition engaging and informative, with many appreciating the interactive elements like breakout rooms and TopHat questions. They enjoyed the clear, step-by-step process of vector addition, with some finding the use of unit vectors and component addition particularly interesting. Real-life applications, such as the hockey and yeti problems, helped students grasp the concepts better. The flipped classroom format, with a brief review followed by problem-solving, was initially unusual for some but ultimately beneficial. Students also appreciated the professor's teaching style and the variety of examples provided.
input:
The format. I've never had a flipped class like this one so it was unusual to have the small time for review and then immediately in to problem solving. I've also never heard vector addition described with the principle of moving backwards along one arrow and that that's why you subtract it (rather than in reference to the idea that origin doesn't matter and therefore whatever the starting location is should be subtracted out from every piece)
It was very entertaining which makes it a lot easier to pay attention too
I think the most interesting part was the use of break out rooms to allow the students to collaborate on a problem
I thought vector additions was the most interesting because of the easy system of steps that need to be followed to solve problems. I really like when things are laid out clearly and the steps are easy to follow. 
I enjoyed when we got to work on the problem in groups of 4. It allowed for discussion between classmates.
The most interesting material in this lecture was using unit vectors to easily add each component of a vector to find its total length.
I found the hockey question interesting because it was challenging but after working in groups we were able to figure it out
I enjoyed going over answers and work during the breakout room session for the one top hat question.
I found adding and subtracting 3 vectors interesting 
I thought it was interesting that cos(x) usually applies to the x-axis, but it's relative to your perspective
 The fact that with the knowledge of vectors you can identify the force and direction of an object being acted on by multiple forces going in different directions.
 I really liked the problem that we did in breakout rooms. This was a good use of time because it allowed for my peers and I to think for ourselves and still be able to get help if needed
 How the vector notations can simplify in multiple dimensions to create either a vector or scalar output.
 I liked the way the professor described vector addition as adding a negative vector. I have never been taught i that way, and it makes vector subtraction much easier.
 I liked getting to use top hat during class and getting put into the break out rooms. I think that it made class more interesting and helped to keep me engaged in what was going on. 
 The thing that I found most interesting was the way he explained how to get the answer and how he showed multiple ways of getting to the answer.
 I was most interested by the break out groups because it allowed us to work on the question together. If one person was stuck we could ask another for help and it's nice to have a peer help sometimes because they have a different viewpoint from the professor or TAs.
 The problem prompts were not boring. 
 How word problems are so easily connected to the topic, and how much easier it is to understand a problem when you draw out the vectors. 
 I really enjoyed doing the TopHat questions in groups. I enjoyed working with others and it felt good helping others with the problem
 I thought it was interesting seeing how, what we learned in the recorded videos, could actually apply to real life situations. 
 The idea that a yeti cannot determine its way and somehow needs the help of gps technology.
 I was able to piece together how to solve the problems we were doing at the end of the lecture and it was satisfying to see myself come to understand how to solve them by the end
 I really enjoyed the way class was formatted! I like that we aren't just repeating the book/notes we took ahead of time. I am fully engaged in practice problems, and thus find them more interesting.
 I found it interesting how much the content overlaps what I'm learning in calculus right now. 
 I like math, so I find setting up vector problems using triangles to be a bit fun.
 I thought that the comparison of altering angles vs using trig on the picture as given was interesting. I'd never actually seen them compared side by side before, it was just something implied or glossed over.
 I found the idea of applied vectors to real situations helpful and interesting. 
 I loved how you outlined your teaching style!  It was awesome to get insight into how you want to run the class.
 The way the theoretical concepts we learned describe real world occurrences like a walking yeti. 
  I realized that you could add vectors by combining their components.

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. **Focus on the main method of vector addition**: Highlight that students found the clear, step-by-step process of vector addition, particularly using unit vectors and component addition, to be the most engaging and informative part of the lecture. This should be the core of the summary.

2. **Emphasize the real-life applications**: Students appreciated the practical examples like the hockey and yeti problems. Mention this in the summary to show how vector addition can be applied to real-world situations, making the topic more relatable and interesting.

3. **Acknowledge the initial adjustment to the flipped classroom format**: While some students found the flipped classroom format initially unusual, they ultimately found it beneficial. This can be briefly mentioned to show that students were able to adapt and find value in the new format.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on vector addition engaging and informative, with the clear, step-by-step process using unit vectors and component addition being the most appreciated aspect. Real-life applications, such as the hockey and yeti problems, helped students grasp the concepts better and understand the practical use of vector addition. While some students initially found the flipped classroom format unusual, they ultimately benefited from the brief review followed by problem-solving. The interactive elements like breakout rooms and TopHat questions also contributed to the overall positive experience.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the groupwork component, facilitated through breakout rooms and TopHat, engaging and beneficial. They appreciated the opportunity to discuss ideas with peers, seek help, and gain different perspectives, with some finding it more helpful than professor or TA assistance. The collaborative problem-solving aspect was highlighted as a key strength, with students enjoying the real-life application of vector concepts in group scenarios like the yeti and hockey problems.
input:
The format. I've never had a flipped class like this one so it was unusual to have the small time for review and then immediately in to problem solving. I've also never heard vector addition described with the principle of moving backwards along one arrow and that that's why you subtract it (rather than in reference to the idea that origin doesn't matter and therefore whatever the starting location is should be subtracted out from every piece)
It was very entertaining which makes it a lot easier to pay attention too
I think the most interesting part was the use of break out rooms to allow the students to collaborate on a problem

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the use of TopHat in class engaging and helpful, with many enjoying the interactive questions and breakout rooms for group collaboration. The TopHat questions, particularly those involving real-life scenarios like a walking yeti or a hockey game, kept students' attention and made learning more interesting. The ability to work in groups and discuss ideas with peers was highlighted as a beneficial aspect of using TopHat. Additionally, students appreciated the immediate feedback and review of answers during the breakout room sessions.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the man and pulley example challenging, particularly the concept of two tensions (2T) acting in opposite directions. Many struggled with understanding why the force pulling the man up is double the tension force, and how to accurately represent this in free body diagrams. Some also expressed confusion about the origin of the two tension vectors and the equations used to solve such problems.

the two tensions instead of one

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the Positive Gravity Representation**: To address the confusion about gravity being represented as positive, consider adding a sentence to the summary explaining that it's convention to represent forces acting upwards as positive and downwards as negative, regardless of their nature (gravity, tension, etc.).

2. **Simplify the Pulleys Explanation**: To make the summary more concise, combine the points about pulleys into one. For example, "Students struggled to understand the concept of two tensions in a pulley system, with some confusion about why the force pulling the crate up was double the tension force."

3. **Combine Related Confusions**: To improve focus, combine related confusions under a single point. For instance, "Students found it challenging to apply free body diagrams to complex scenarios involving multiple forces, masses, and pulleys, as well as problems with multiple objects in contact, such as blocks pushing against each other." This maintains the key points while making the summary more concise.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found free body diagrams challenging, particularly when applied to complex scenarios involving multiple forces and objects. Confusion arose from representing gravity as positive (a convention where upwards forces are positive), and the concept of two tensions in pulley systems, with students struggling to understand why the force pulling the crate up was double the tension force. Students also found it challenging to apply free body diagrams to problems with multiple objects in contact, such as blocks pushing against each other. Some students felt that the lecture could have benefited from more challenging, conceptual questions to deepen their understanding.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the concept of tension, particularly in scenarios involving pulleys and multiple objects. The free body diagrams for these scenarios also posed challenges, with students unsure about where to place force vectors and how to account for multiple tensions. Some students found the transition from simple to more complex problems difficult, wishing for harder examples to better grasp the concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of forces between objects, particularly tension, challenging to grasp. Many were confused by the presence of two tensions in pulley problems, with some struggling to understand why the force pulling a crate up is double the tension force. Free body diagrams (FBDs) were another source of confusion, with students finding it difficult to set them up correctly and understand the origin of tension vectors. Some also found it challenging to apply these concepts to more complex scenarios, like multiple masses pushing on each other. A few students suggested that more complex examples could have been used to better illustrate these concepts.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the use of 'T' in pulley problems**: Instead of mentioning "double tension" repeatedly, specify that 'T' represents the tension in the rope, and when a pulley is involved, the force needed to lift the object is equal to 'T' (not '2T'). This would help clear up confusion about why the force pulling a crate up is 'T', not '2T'.

   *Revised*: "Students struggled with the concept of tension in pulley problems, often mistakenly thinking the force pulling an object up should be '2T' instead of 'T'."

2. **Emphasize the importance of defining the system**: Highlight the need for students to clearly define the system when dealing with forces between multiple objects. This could help address confusion about which forces to include in free body diagrams and how to determine the direction of acceleration.

   *Revised*: "Students found it challenging to apply forces between objects to complex scenarios, often struggling to define the system correctly."

3. **Provide a concise summary of free body diagram (FBD) confusion**: Combine the various points about FBDs into a single, concise statement to avoid repetition and maintain focus on the main topic.

   *Revised*: "Students found setting up free body diagrams challenging, often struggling to identify all forces acting on an object, determine the correct direction of force vectors, and understand the origin of tension vectors."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY**: Students found the concept of forces between objects, particularly tension, challenging to grasp. Many were confused by the presence of tension in pulley problems, mistakenly thinking the force pulling an object up should be '2T' instead of 'T'. Free body diagrams (FBDs) were another source of confusion, with students struggling to identify all forces acting on an object, determine the correct direction of force vectors, and understand the origin of tension vectors. When applying these concepts to complex scenarios, students often struggled to define the system correctly, leading to difficulties in determining the direction of acceleration and including the appropriate forces in their FBDs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of coefficient of friction engaging, with many appreciating its practical applications and real-life examples. They were particularly interested in learning about the relationship between normal force and friction, and how this relationship influences the ease of moving objects. Several students found it counterintuitive yet fascinating that surface area does not affect friction, with normal force and the friction coefficient being the key factors. The variety of problems and examples, including those involving sandpaper, blocks, and a sled, helped reinforce their understanding. Many students enjoyed the interactive TopHat questions and group discussions, which allowed them to apply their knowledge and deepen their understanding of the coefficient of friction.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning 'cold welds' and 'atomic interactions causing friction' separately, combine them as 'students found the molecular-level explanation of friction, including 'cold welds', interesting'.

2. **Clarify Coefficient of Friction**: To avoid confusion, explicitly state that the coefficient of static friction can be greater than 1, but the force of static friction cannot exceed the normal force. This was a point of surprise for some students (e.g., "The coefficient of friction, either static or kinetic, is usually smaller than 1.").

3. **Highlight Key Relationships**: Emphasize the key relationship between static friction and the normal force, and how it changes with applied force. This was a major point of interest for many students and is crucial to understanding static friction. Consider rephrasing it as: "Students were particularly interested in understanding how the force of static friction relates to the normal force and how this relationship changes with the application of external forces."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the topic of static friction engaging, appreciating real-life examples and interactive TopHat questions. They were intrigued by the concept that while the coefficient of static friction (μs) can be greater than 1, the force of static friction (Fs) cannot exceed the normal force (Fn), i.e., Fs ≤ μs * Fn. Students were particularly interested in understanding how the force of static friction relates to the normal force and how this relationship changes with the application of external forces. The molecular-level explanation of friction, including 'cold welds', was found to be fascinating.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of normal force and its relationship with friction engaging. They appreciated learning how normal force, not surface area, influences friction, as demonstrated in problems like the sandpaper block on a ramp. The idea that friction can be reduced by lifting an object, thus decreasing the normal force, was also intriguing. Some students struggled initially with the concept, but group discussions and top hat questions helped clarify their understanding.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the phrase "tensions don't add"**: Instead of "why tensions don't add," consider "why tensions are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction." This phrasing aligns better with the concept of Newton's Third Law and might reduce confusion.

2. **Specify the direction confusion**: Instead of "determining their directions," suggest "identifying the direction of tension forces based on the pull or direction of motion." This provides a more actionable understanding of the direction confusion.

3. **Highlight the tug of war problem**: Instead of mentioning both the tug of war problem and the salami question, focus solely on the tug of war problem as it was mentioned more frequently and seemed to cause more confusion. Suggest: "The tug of war problem, where students struggled to understand why the force of tension was between two values, warranted further explanation."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with tension problems, particularly understanding why tensions are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, and identifying the direction of tension forces based on the pull or direction of motion. Many found conceptual questions and real-life examples challenging. The tug of war problem, where students struggled to understand why the force of tension was between two values, warranted further explanation and practice. Some students appreciated the mathematical clarity, while others sought more integration of mathematical and conceptual aspects.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Inertial vs Non-inertial Frames**: Students found the distinction between inertial and non-inertial frames confusing. Consider dedicating more time to explaining the key differences and providing clear, relatable examples, such as the car analogy mentioned by a student.

2. **Elaborate on Phantom Forces**: Several students were unclear about phantom forces. While the professor explained it thoroughly, providing additional examples or a brief recap in the summary could help reinforce understanding.

To make the summary more concise and focused, suggest explicitly stating that tension forces always act along the line connecting the points of contact, and provide a simple rule for their direction (e.g., "tension pulls apart").

Additionally, students requested explicit guidance on tension force directions (e.g., "tension pulls apart" along the line connecting points of contact) and more practical problems connecting Newton's laws to equations.

2. **Combine Similar Points**: Group together similar student reflections to make the summary more concise.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on the Right-Hand Rule mostly clear, with some confusion persisting among several. While the car demonstration and Top Hat questions were praised for enhancing understanding, the Right-Hand Rule itself remained challenging for many. Some students struggled with applying the rule to 2D graphs or determining the direction of vectors, while others found the distinction between positive and negative vectors confusing. A few students suggested more examples or clearer explanations could help solidify their understanding of this topic.
input:
The right-hand rule and how to use coordinate plane with just x and z values (as opposed to x and y).
I found everything to be fairly straightforward during today's lecture. Graphs of derivatives confused me a bit, so maybe more time could be spent on that.
The explanations of the cross product were very informative, and the practice problems really helped to clarify the topic
I thought today's lecture was very clear. I appreciated the car demonstration, as well as the Top Hat questions. It helped me stay engaged and better understand the topics covered.
I could follow along easily in this lecture. One thing that could've used more explaining was the right hand rule top hat question. 
Everything was clear during this lecture. I had no confusion and I understood everything from the clicker questions. 
I was quite confused with the x,y,a, axis top hat question. I didnt quite understand the placement of the z axis (axis coming out/into the screen).

Cross products and into vs out of screen.
It was unclear how much time we would have in our groups to answer the tophat questions.
 I am a little confused about the last example we were doing, but when I thought over after class, I figured out the answers.
 right hand method. I will never understand. The top hat question about that rule made no sense to me. 
 Drawing position, velocity, and acceleration graphs. I had trouble with this in high school and still do not fully understand it 
 The one problem where the hypotenuse was facing the wrong direction was a little confusing at first. It went right over my head when I did the problem. The explanation for it was very good though. 
 the derivation and explanation of formulas for acceleration and velocity could've been covered and used in examples more
 i was still a little confused about the position velocity and acceleration graphs. i always get confused when interpreting them. i'll definitely go watch some youtube videos about it but it would go a little more in depth

How to find acceleration in relative motion in both 1D and 2D
I am still confused on a part of the dinosaur problem we discussed. Does each dinosaur have to have its own positive and negative direction or can one be used for the whole system?
What was a little confusing in today's lecture was determining which kinematic formula we needed to start with
The dinosaur example was confusing. The explanation at the end made sense, but I think we could've used another example to help clarify. 
The most confusing part of the lecture was the tophat question about the dinosaurs. I didn't understand why both the accelerations were positive
Going in depth for more problems in class
In today's lecture the only thing that was confusing was the effects of constant speed on acceleration.
There was a large amount of calculus in these videos with derivatives that I don't remember well. Therefore, the math was a little but hard to follow. Also, average and instantaneous velocities and speeds etc. start to blend together after a while and get to be harder to differentiate, especially in terms of what they mean conceptually. 
nothing was really confusing, the lectures explained the material well
I think the explanations of average and instantaneous velocity and acceleration were a bit confusing based on the graph examples.
 The discussion around direction and sign.

 average and instantaneous velocity and acceleration still confuses me

 Nothing that we went over was confusing or unclear for me today. I guess that if would've been more clear to spend a bit more time on the dinosaur problem. Perhaps going into more detail as to how you obtained the setup for the problem.

 direction of acceleration during circular motion
 I didn't understand the circular motion aspect of today's lecture. I will watch the lectures for Friday but I might need more review Friday.
 There was not much that was confusing I just think I need to have more practice with using the kinematic equations.

 Circular motion and how acceleration works with it.
 the question we had to answer in breakout rooms was confusing at first, but became simpler when explained
 The thing that confused me about the lecture was how clockwise, and counter clockwise are not vectors. However when you said vectors can't be curved, I realized that rotating vector wouldn't be able to work. 
 During the dinosaur example problem, I was confused on how adding their accelerations still resulted in the right answer.
 The concept of keeping what negative or positive was a bit confusing
 The second last question was a bit confusing but Dr. Nero explained it perfectly 
 The graphs picturing their difference between average and instantaneous velocity.
 The first question with the two Dinos was very confusing at first but once my group knew how to use the displacement we were fine. 
 conceptual questions such as if you can accelerate while at constant speed or where the direction of acceleration would be based on direction of velocity

 The speed, velocity, and acceleration we talked about towards the end
 We could maybe look at other ways to solve the dinosaur question. I know some people in my group used calculus for it, but potentially other kinematics and substitutions. (Although these would probably take longer)
 Using quadratic equation; just not used to using it for physics 
 In the Physics class at my high school we used different variable in the kinematic equations.
 nothing, it all made sense, but I took physics in high school so I already knew the concepts. 
 The second top hat question regarding two objects colliding. We haven't been taught/ reviewed how to use kinematics with more than one object 
 more explanation as to why certain numbers are negative and what makes a velocity/acceleration a negative value

To address this, instructors could simplify explanations, use visual aids, and provide more worked examples, focusing on the direction of acceleration and the difference between clockwise and counterclockwise motion.

pred: SUMMARY: Today's lecture on Vector Math focused on clarifying the use of sine and cosine functions, and when to add or subtract vectors. Students appreciated the clear explanations but sought more detailed walkthroughs of numerical problems and unit vectors. Confusion persisted around when to add or subtract vectors, especially in word problems, and how to determine the direction of resultant vectors. Some students also struggled with understanding when to add 180 degrees to angles. The use of Top Hat for interactive questions was initially challenging for some, but they adapted as the lecture progressed. Overall, students found the lecture efficient and informative, with a few areas for further clarification needed.
input:
Just a quick review of when to use sin vs cos in vector math and which angles to apply, depending on which function is chosen (just because they are, technically, interchangeable)
How to stack the vectors from head to tail. When is it allowed, and when is it not?
Today's lecture was clear and for the most part easy to follow. The only part that I still am confused on is using unit vectors. However, I believe this will be covered in more detail with the next lecture.
I was confused about angle conversions in this lecture. I understand that you add based off of what quadrant the vector is in, but on an in-class example that rule didn't work, and I needed to subtract 360°. 
I think it would be more beneficial if you would go in depth of your pictures drawn and explain how they apply to a numerical problem even more.
I didn't find anything confusing or unclear during today's class. I have already taken 2 years of physics, so I know this content very well and is something I'm very comfortable with. I believe the way you taught it is very similar to how I first learned the material.
One thing I will definitely need to be looking more in to is the subtraction of vectors from the Yeti problem, when solving on my own i had a slightly different answer, so I will be trying to figure out why.
Overall, the lecture was efficient and assessed everything that was taught throughout the online lecture videos. However, going a little slower throughout the problems to let students understand and catch up through every step will allow for more information absorption. Also, during the top hat questions, it could've been more informative to go over why the incorrect answers were actually wrong.
I believe that what is most confusing to me about the lecture is when to use sin and cos for x and y, and occasionally where to put the angle given. I think i confuse myself when it comes to sin and cos. 
I was initially confused on how subtracting vectors worked but I figured it out
 Nothing extremely confusing this time around. Just to make sure, whenever you need to find the vector from one tip of a vector to another one, when both are going in a different direction from the origin, you have to subtract, right?
 I thought today's class went very well. I do not think that I did not misunderstand any of the topics discussed during the class. I found the problem we did in breakout rooms very helpful because it allowed for my group and I to think for ourselves.
 How the right-hand rule can be manipulated to apply to the cross product and how unit vectors create a direction.
 I am familiar with vectors which was the topic of the lecture. I thought the professor gave enough details for me. 
 There was nothing that proved to be confusing or unclear in today's class. 
 There wasn't anything really confusing about today's lecture. I had a little trouble with the top hat questions however I seemed to get the hang of it by the end. I liked that the teacher drew the graphs and vectors. 
 I was confused by the question about the atoms whose positions were represented by vectors stemming from the same origin. The idea of vectors representing positions led me to believe it was a collision problem so I struggled to set it up.
 When values should be positive or negative and when it is necessary to add 180 to an angle. 
 I'm confused about the direction a negative vector points when it is added to a positive vector. 
 I didn't find anything that was confusing. The content videos before the lecture were very helpful for preparing.

 Sometimes I felt like issues with TopHat (not always my own) took away from the explanation of answers, but these are just temporary as we all get used to the format.
 Most of the material covered today is content I have seen before so it was not confusing at all. The clicker questions were explained clearly. They only thing that is sometimes confusing is navigating canvas.
 didn't have much trouble with any of the concepts presented in the lecture today. I have taken physics so this was a pretty basic review

I was confused throughout the video on how to know whether or not to subtract or add vectors based on the specific question, but I believe that is more so me understanding the problem and how to properly draw out the graph and vectors and understanding what the question is asking us to do than the actual math itself. Therefore I believe that with additional lectures and practice I will have it down!

For me personally, I still had questions by the end of the lecture about what/how to use Piazza, TopHat, and Sapling. Luckily, everything was figured out by our second meeting through your clarification and other students help. 
 How the direction of a resultant vector compares to the value. I have trouble understanding their relationship.

 The only thing I found confusing in today's lecture was the second top hat question we did. I was confused about how to determine whether we would add the vectors or subtract them. 
 There was nothing confusing to me in today's lecture.
 The first multiple choice question confused me today. I was not sure how to do it or where to start but after the explanation I understand why the answer was B. 
 I was a little confused about the way tophat worked at the beginning of the lecture and how much time we would have for each part but after I used it for the first question I got the hang of it. 
 Everything was explained very well and in detail. I used law of sines and cosines for some problems but that's just cause I prefer it that way. 
 The only new thing to me was the idea of subtracting vectors. For example the top hat question was asking if you would add or subtract/which way you would subtract. However, with examples I was able to understand. I did like the breakout groups and getting to discuss with classmates. I also wish that the comment section was geared more towards questions and not comments because questions can get lost. Thanks.
 How, even with having to visualizing a resultant vector, the two addition vectors do not need to be visualized tip to tail.

 I had a bit of trouble interacting with others in the breakout rooms, but that is something I will work on improving myself. 
 I just don't understand when we subtract and don't add. I understand why we have to subtract certain ways but when do we subtract?

 Using Top Hat/getting used to using Top Hat was a bit confusing and tough. I wasn't always sure when to submit answers, how much time I had, and I had some trouble getting out of the zoom window quickly and to the Top Hat one. I think the more practice I get with it though the better I'll get at it. 
 The video was good today, and the worked out examples helped. I personally wasn't as prepared as I needed to be for class because this is my first flipped class ever. I look foreword to improving this for next class though.
 Maybe some clarification on when it is necessary to add 180 degrees to the answer of some problems and specifically how to identify when to do that both before you answer the problem and after. 
 I followed along very well in today's lecture, but I wish I had a bit more practice before answering the TOPHAT questions. I watched/did the extra problems and videos in addition to the quiz.

 I am slightly confused about Unit Vectors. It would have been nice to have a bit more context or explanation about this topic.

For example, in the yeti problem I did not know if you were supposed to add the two vectors or subtract them. The same goes for the Top Hat question earlier. in class regarding RA and RB. My instinct is to always add it it confuses me on when to subtract.

(Side note: on the concept quizzes, I feel like there should be a note that you only have one opportunity to get full points, following that you'll lose points for each attempt.)

I know you said that negative vectors wouldn't be used much but I still think it was a confusing topic. Thank you!

1. **Vector Addition/Subtraction**: Students struggled to understand when to add or subtract vectors, especially in word problems, and how to determine the direction of the resultant vector.

2. **Angle Manipulation**: Students found it challenging to understand when and why to add 180 degrees to angles in vector problems.

3. **Top Hat Adaptation**: Initially, students struggled with using Top Hat for interactive questions but adapted as the lecture progressed.

Overall, the lecture was efficient and informative, with these areas identified for further clarification.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on angles clear and engaging, with a few areas of confusion. Some also expressed difficulty in understanding unit vectors and their purpose. Overall, students appreciated the clarity of the lecture and felt they had a good grasp on the topic.

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. **Clarify Angle Manipulation**: To address the confusion around adding or subtracting 180 degrees from angles, provide a clear rule or guideline in the summary, such as: "When dealing with angles in the range of 0° to 360°, students should add 180° if the angle is in the second or third quadrant, or subtract 180° if it's in the fourth quadrant."

2. **Emphasize Angle Direction**: To help students understand the direction of resultant vectors, the summary could emphasize the importance of considering the angle's direction in relation to the positive x-axis, rather than just its magnitude. For example: "Students should pay attention to the angle's direction (clockwise or counterclockwise from the positive x-axis) when determining the direction of the resultant vector."

3. **Simplify Unit Vectors**: To make the concept of unit vectors clearer, the summary could simplify it to: "Unit vectors are vectors with a magnitude of 1, used to represent direction. They are created by dividing a vector by its magnitude." This simplification could help students understand their purpose and how to work with them.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on angles clear and engaging, with most understanding the use of sine and cosine in vector math and the application of angles based on the chosen function. However, some students struggled with determining when to add or subtract 180 degrees from angles. To clarify, when dealing with angles in the range of 0° to 360°, students should add 180° if the angle is in the second or third quadrant, or subtract 180° if it's in the fourth quadrant. Additionally, students found it challenging to determine the direction of resultant vectors. To address this, students should pay attention to the angle's direction (clockwise or counterclockwise from the positive x-axis) when determining the direction of the resultant vector. Lastly, some students expressed difficulty understanding unit vectors. To simplify, unit vectors are vectors with a magnitude of 1, used to represent direction. They are created by dividing a vector by its magnitude. Overall, students appreciated the clarity of the lecture and felt they had a good grasp on the topic.

A few students expressed confusion about when to add 180 degrees to an angle in their responses.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) engaging, particularly in solving problems involving pulley systems and forces. They appreciated learning the "recipe" for drawing FBDs, which made the process easier. The concept of forces having resisting components and the ability to change the system analyzed to simplify calculations were also noted as interesting. Many found the conceptual questions challenging yet intriguing, and the use of FBDs to solve problems like the Atwood machine and ice block problems was particularly insightful. Students also valued the practical application of FBDs in real-life scenarios, such as in industry and everyday situations.
input:

top hat

drawing free body diagrams to set up equations

 the use of free bodies to solve the atwood machine problem with forces

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of two blocks interacting with forces and systems challenging, with several expressing confusion about the last problem involving two blocks on a frictionless surface. Friction on an incline was what confused me. When more than one or two forces are applied, I feel like things are bound to get confusing.

stacked bodys

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of friction, particularly in scenarios involving multiple blocks or surfaces, challenging to grasp. The last problem of the lecture, featuring two blocks with varying coefficients of friction, was the most confusing for many. Some struggled with combining free body diagrams, determining which forces to use, and understanding why certain equations were applied. A few also sought clarification on the difference between static and kinetic friction, the purpose of the maximum static friction (fs_max), and how to reliably create equivalent, solvable problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) mostly clear, but several concepts caused confusion. The primary challenges were understanding FBDs for systems with multiple blocks, especially when involving friction and different surfaces (frictionless vs. friction). Students struggled with combining FBDs for these systems and determining which forces to include. The last top hat question, involving two blocks with one sliding on the other, was particularly confusing due to the complexity of the system and the need to consider both blocks' FBDs. Some students also sought clarification on the difference between static and kinetic friction, and the purpose of the maximum static friction (fs_max).

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat questions engaging and helpful in solidifying their understanding of forces and Newton's laws. They particularly enjoyed the real-world scenarios like the spaceship, tug of war, and scale examples, as they made complex concepts more relatable and easier to visualize. The interactive nature of the questions also allowed them to gauge their understanding and compare their responses with their peers. Some students, however, wished for more time to answer these questions.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: The summary mentions "students found" and "they appreciated" multiple times. Instead, use varied sentence structures to convey the same information, e.g., "Students discovered the usefulness of histograms..." and "They valued the practical application of these concepts in Excel."

2. **Focus on key learning points**: The summary tries to cover too many aspects. Narrow it down to the most significant learning points, such as understanding when to use histograms, creating and editing them in Excel, and comparing data sets using a single graph.

3. **Avoid mentioning specific tools (Excel) unless necessary**: While Excel was mentioned in many reflections, it's not the core topic. Instead of saying "in Excel," consider saying "in a spreadsheet software" or "digitally" to keep the focus on the concepts rather than the tool.

**Revised Summary (based on suggestions):**
SUMMARY: Students discovered the usefulness of histograms, graphs, and charts, with a particular emphasis on understanding when and how to use histograms. They valued the practical application of these concepts in a spreadsheet software, finding it engaging to create and edit histograms digitally. The in-class assignment and group discussions, especially in breakout rooms, were highlighted as valuable learning experiences. Students found it intriguing to learn about comparing data sets using a single graph and manipulating histograms to display data effectively. They expressed enthusiasm for continuing to develop their skills in using these tools for data analysis.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on histograms, graphs, and charts engaging, with a particular focus on understanding when and how to use histograms. They valued the practical application of these concepts in a spreadsheet software, finding it rewarding to create and edit histograms digitally. The in-class assignment and group discussions, especially in breakout rooms, were highlighted as valuable learning experiences. Students found it intriguing to learn about comparing data sets using a single graph and manipulating histograms to display data effectively. They expressed enthusiasm for continuing to develop their skills in using these tools for data analysis.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Excel's graphing capabilities, particularly histograms, engaging and informative. They appreciated learning when and how to use different types of graphs, with histograms being a standout topic due to their versatility in organizing and displaying data. The in-class group activities, including breakout rooms, were well-received, providing opportunities for peer interaction and idea exchange. Students also enjoyed learning to format and manipulate histograms in Excel, expressing excitement about improving their Excel skills.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Instead of repeatedly mentioning "found interesting," use phrases like "discovered," "noted," or simply "learned" to convey the same idea more concisely.
   - *Original*: "I found it interesting how many planets I would need."
   - *Revised*: "I discovered how many planets would be needed if everyone lived like me."

2. **Combine similar points**: Group related reflections together to make the summary more streamlined.
   - *Original*: "The time in break rooms was very helpful for getting some team work accomplished." and "I enjoyed the long amounts of time we had to work as a team on the assignment."
   - *Revised*: "Students appreciated the extended time allocated for teamwork, finding it helpful for accomplishing group tasks and staying on the same page with their teammates."

3. **Highlight specific teamwork activities**: Instead of general mentions of teamwork, emphasize the specific tasks and activities that students found engaging and beneficial.
   - *Original*: "Working on the solar panel project."
   - *Revised*: "Students particularly enjoyed collaborative tasks such as calculating total solar panel costs and discussing trade-offs with their teammates."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students discovered the value of teamwork in the lecture, with many appreciating the extended time allocated for group work on Assignment 13. They found collaborative tasks such as calculating carbon footprints, determining total solar panel costs, and discussing trade-offs with their teammates to be engaging and beneficial. The time allowed for teamwork helped students stay on the same page and solve problems more effectively.
